feed.title: Hugh Duong-Tran-Tien
feed.subtitle: I'm Hugh, web developer, writer, and wannabe open-sourcerer.

entry.title: A little passion project: Poke-Profiles
entry.content:
Introduction

Hey everyone, Happy to update that I‚Äôve just wrapped up the first release of a little project that I‚Äôve been working on called Poke-Profiles! It‚Äôs been a bit of a challenge to get together some time after work/ weekends to spend time on this. However, I‚Äôve finally managed to get it to a point where I‚Äôm fairly happy with it. I wouldn‚Äôt call it perfect but I had a pretty good crack at it. I‚Äôm actually quite proud of the result. It‚Äôs possibly the best thing I‚Äôve been able to produce all on my own. You‚Äôll be able to have a look at it here.

Inspiration

I‚Äôm trying to remember exactly what kickstarted the sudden surge of motivation to start a project and then try to get it completed. Anyway, somehow while browsing the internet I stumbled upon this. My first immediate thought was ‚Äòthis is so epic‚Äô. The second thought was ‚Äòwait at minute, I remember coming across a PokeAPI library a while ago. Shouldn‚Äôt I be able to make this?‚Äô. And so, off I went.

Planning

I have a tendency to procrastinate on youtube. Don‚Äôt judge me, I‚Äôm sure everyone does. Regardless, I stumbled across this guy - Florin Pop. He did a fantastic challenge called ‚Äú10 coding projects in 10 hours‚Äù. I felt super inspired by this and a lot of the javascript groundwork stems from these projects. You can check out the github here.

Anyway, enough fanboying. I basically used these projects to set out a scope, technology stack and architecture. I didn‚Äôt really want/ need to build a full on fullstack application (like the ones I do for work). Reason being that it would take a lot of work and there‚Äôs only one me with not a lot of time. When in doubt, I can always rely on the basics. Simple HTML/CSS/Javascript will do the job. Since it‚Äôs my project, I can make it as simple or as complicated as I want. That‚Äôs a freedom I can afford. Of course there are drawbacks and advantages to just using vanilla javascript but I‚Äôll take it as a learning exprience.

The main star of the project really though is PokeAPI. All I really need to do is connect this to my page and when I do a search for a pokemon, it‚Äôll bring me all the information I can possible want about that searched pokemon. It‚Äôs like magic.

The main challenge is then implementing the layout and make it look impressive. It needs to work across mobile and desktop platforms - in this project I worked with a mobile-first design strategy. You can read more about it here.

The second challenge is optimization, I want the experience to feel seamless and fast. Luckily for me, the guys at PokeAPI also made a little javascript wrapper that uses serviceworkers to sort out caching for images. Basically that means once you load an image, it hangs around so that if you search the same pokemon again it‚Äôll load faster.

With those things nutted out, I was ready to get cracking.

Features

Search function

There‚Äôs a jQuery UI widget integrated into the app to sort out the search functionality. Basically works as you would expect. Type in any letter and it‚Äôll filter search for a list of relevant pokemon in alphabetical order. It‚Äôll also highlight the letters you search for aswell, neat!

You can search by either clicking a select option or typing out the name entirely and pressing enter.

Currently, there‚Äôs no hard validation warning when you type in a pokemon that doesn‚Äôt exist. There‚Äôs a little unintended feature from the search filter that tells you it didn‚Äôt find any pokemon with your search parameters though. Kinda serves the same purpose, but doesn‚Äôt let you know a search as failed on submission. (I‚Äôll add this later, I swear)

Images
Search functionality

Pokemon details

When you do a search, you should get the following details:

  • Pokemon ID
  • Pokemon Name
  • Pokemon Japanese Name
  • Height
  • Weight
  • Region
  • Type (as image)
  • Stats (HP/ Attack/ Defense/ Sp Attack/ Sp Defense/ Speed)
  • A randomly chosen pokemon description (some of you may recognize it‚Äôs the official pokedex entry description from the anime)
  • The background color will also change depending on the pokemon‚Äôs primary type

The information layout is slightly different for mobile version because it looked better that way.

Loading icon

When you do a search and the app is taking it‚Äôs sweet time to bring you all the information, you should see a loading icon until it‚Äôs ready to show you the pokemon.

Images
Loading animation

Challenges

I don‚Äôt really want to make you sit here and read through all the challenges I went through so I‚Äôll just riff off that main ones and how I overcame them.

Problem 1 - Sticking to the design layout

As you can tell, the layout for the desktop version is not really in a standard web template. I had to experiment quite a bit to get it really nice the way it is. Of course, you can also tell it doesn‚Äôt match the design template 100%. Reason for this was because the image size gets really pixelated when I scale it up. Since I‚Äôm grabbing the image from an API and don‚Äôt really want to do anything more than scaling it up. I can just re-arrange things to make it look nice. In this case, I should treat the design template as a guide rather than strict ruleset. Plus, it was a really good experience to train my eye for these type of things. I used CSS Grid to implement the design and let me tell you, the MVP Tool was the firefox developer console. It makes generates grid guidelines which make it really easy to see whether things align and helps me positions things easier. (Also helped me get my head around CSS Grid as I had never really used it before - TLDR; you should basically treat it like excel cells)

Problem 2 - Loading times

In an effort to make my code look cleaner, I re-wrote some things and wrapped the API calls in async/ await functions. I also figured out that I could get the Japanese translations from the API call as well - but this needed me to make two API calls instead of one. This actually slowed down my code a little bit since the second call would have to wait for the first call to finish before executing. I haven‚Äôt been able to find a good solution that I could easily implement. The next best thing was to add a loader animation so that at least the user would know to wait rather than just looking at a frozen screen until something changed.

Looking backwards

I know the application isn‚Äôt perfect. There‚Äôs little bits here and there that could use some work. I‚Äôve tried my hardest to crack down on the majority of bugs and feature enhancements to get it to its current state. I think if I don‚Äôt do a bit of reflection now to remind myself what the original goal of the project was, I might get caught up on a perpetual loop of enhancing these minor things to make it perfect.

While that‚Äôs nice to do, I don‚Äôt think there‚Äôs much progress to be had in spending an extra chunk of time sorting them out. I‚Äôm a big believer in the 80/20 rule and I think it applies here pretty well.

I started just wanting to build someting. I wrung out a scope and mostly stuck to it. I built a fairly awesome looking site and wrote documentation for it. I learnt so much along the way; got to understand what I‚Äôm comfortable doing and what my shortcomings are. It‚Äôs not about the destination but the journey. Plus I‚Äôve used up the initial spark of motivation weeks ago. My discipline has gotten me this far and I only have a little bit of strength left to write down my thoughts and plans for the future if I ever decide to revist the project.

Looking forwards

Now that I‚Äôm writing this reflection piece, I‚Äôm actually feeling quite fulfilled with the amount of work I‚Äôve been able to get done. I‚Äôm also a little excited to wait a while and get back to work on it. Which is good I think!

Like I said, I‚Äôve tried to keep documentation up to date on the github repository. There‚Äôs a list of changelogs there. But basically the major things to work on are the loading times and perhaps a refactor. It could also do with some fancy animations and sounds effects. Oh! And I should probably get the cool pagination things done. I‚Äôm imagining a little scrolling effect I could add. There‚Äôs actually a bit to do!

For another time though. üòÄ

Wrapping up

That‚Äôs all folks! Thanks for reading until the end. If you‚Äôre interested in what else I have to say, you can check out my other posts below.

Hugh
entry.summary: Hey all, I've been working on a little web app for the past month and half. I wanted to write a brief summary of the inspiration, process, what the current product looks like and perhaps a bit of reflection.

entry.title: There‚Äôs no fun in fundamentals
entry.content:
First things first

Please excuse the bad humour in the title. It‚Äôs 2AM and I just had a flash of inspiration to write down some thoughts; a little food for thought for those who want/need to hear it. Full warning, no TL;DR for this one. If a wall of text intimidates you, I won‚Äôt scoff at you for leaving. Or maybe I will? Guess we‚Äôll find out.

Second things second

UnFortunately, recent developments in my life have sort of forced me out of my comfort zone and into somewhat of a uh-oh-panic-zone.

Why? Simple - job interviews.

More specifically, algorithms. I know. Yuck. Well‚Ä¶ actually, now that I‚Äôve been studying them for a couple of weeks, algorithmic thinking is actually kinda cool. What‚Äôs not cool, is staying up to 2AM and furiously sipping my tea because I can‚Äôt seem to figure out what‚Äôs wrong with my code. Anyway, I digress. To keep things short, I‚Äôm planning to be out in the job market again soon.

And for those you don‚Äôt know, I‚Äôve only just started my career. So my experience in job-hunting is, how should I say, close to zero. I got very lucky to land an internship and then even luckier to turn that into a temporary full-time position until the end of the year. As such, I don‚Äôt really know what typical employers want or are looking for. All I have is a handful of anecdotal evidence from work mates and opinions on reddit. Oh, and a whole bunch of ex-techleads turned youtubers who have likely skewed my understanding of job-seeking as a junior developer.

From my own experience and what I have been told, in the tech industry, job interviews usually mean code interviews. For those who have the pleasure of not knowing the kind of nerve-wracking life-altering experience that can be, good for you. I‚Äôm happy for you. I‚Äôve done a couple before and trust me when I say they‚Äôre not fun. Please pray for me if you have time. If you don‚Äôt that‚Äôs okay too. Just know any love is appreciated so please send them my way.

Anyway, yeah. Finding a new job = having to take some code interviews. For junior devs, in general, they involve being given a computational problem and coming up with an algorithm to provide a solution to said problem. This usually happens one on one with another senior dev. Imagine doing a math test alone in a room with your teacher as they breathe down your neck judging everything you write. That pretty much sums up what it feels like.

That being said, coming up with a ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù solution isn‚Äôt usually the goal - it‚Äôs really meant to help the senior dev gauge your coding ability and communication skills. There‚Äôs a bunch of debate on whether this system is appropriate (or even good) but that‚Äôs a topic for another day. I want to talk about me. The reason I don‚Äôt like them is because I suck at them. Reason being, these interviews don‚Äôt have test you on the stuff you‚Äôll be doing on the job, they test your theory skills. In practice, most jobs teach devs skills that revolve around the business product, not algorithmic thinking. Anywho, just in case, I thought I should do some study. And turns out I‚Äôm actually quite enjoying it so it‚Äôs not all bad.

Learnings

Early on I recognised one thing. I have no idea how to solve these problems. The reason why I had no idea was because my fundamentals were lacking. There was nothing for me to rely on when I got stuck. I was perpetually stuck in a loop of trial-and-error and brute-forcing solutions, and when that didn‚Äôt work, I gave up.

So here‚Äôs the moral of the story. Master the basics. Go back and really solidify your fundamentals. The bread and butter of the skillset. You should be able to rely on them just as you rely on breathing instinctively to live. There‚Äôs a neat little article talking about it here. Credit to Dallas Blowers for the insightful read.

For those who want to skip the read. It basically re-iterates what I said. You shouldn‚Äôt rush to progress, take the time to digest the basics. Learning to rely on them will be the difference between life and death (figuratively). But of course, it‚Äôs not fun to just grind basic drills everyday. I think it takes a intention to apply those basics that will make the difference. Maybe you can do something fun or crazy with what you just learnt. See if you can use them the wrong way (to see works and what doesn‚Äôt). But most importantly, have fun with it people!

Hope this serves you well.

Hugh
entry.summary: But there is fun in fundamentals! I know, I know. If you have a little bit of time, I'd like to explore it a little further.

entry.title: Welcome to Git: The Cheatsheet
entry.content:
Hey everyone! üëã I‚Äôve recently been experimenting and learning more about Git as a versioning control tool. Thought I would share some things I‚Äôve learnt and also some quick snippets of what I use on a day-to-day basis.

This is more of a guide for Git for Windows (as that is what I‚Äôm using). If you have installed Git, you should be able run Git Bash to run the unix commands. Another option is to install a Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) in VSCode and use that instead (my preference).

The basics

Usually the first thing you learn in git is how to save your working directory onto a git branch

# Usually you do something like this
git add . 
git commit -m "Example update"

You can actually save a bit of time by combining the add & commit into one line, like so

# Add & Commit combined
git commit -am "Cheeky one liner"

Neat! But there‚Äôs actually an even faster way to do this - by using Aliases

The git config command allows you to create aliases that can shorten existing commands or create custom commands. For instance we can shorten this ‚Äú-am‚Äù command to something like this

# Create alias
git config --global alias.ac "commit -am"

# So now we can do this
git ac "Speedy!" // Equivalent of git commit -am "Speedy!"

Amend

Sometimes a good commit message can be alot more valuable than a code comment.

A quick git log can show you a timeline of commits and give you picture of how the code has changed. Making a mistake on these messages can lead to confusion.

So what if we wanted to change the message of our last commit?

# Change message of last commit
git commit --amend -m "Fixed!"

And if you forgot to add some files that you want to commit aswell?

# Add everything
git add .

# Amend with the same message
git commit --amend -no-edit

Keep in mind, this only works if you haven‚Äôt pushed it to a remote repository.

Revert

If you want to revert a previous commit that you pushed on a remote repository, you can use this command

git revert "[commit]"

Codespaces

This is probably the coolest thing I came across. Let‚Äôs say you‚Äôre somewhere and don‚Äôt have VScode or Git installed. You can simply go to the github repository and tap the . key to open up a web instance of VScode where you commit make changes to the file there.

That‚Äôs all for now, but I‚Äôll make sure to keep this updated when I find new things!

Thanks all! üòÄ
entry.summary: Hey everyone! üëã I‚Äôve recently been experimenting and learning more about Git as a versioning control tool. Thought I would share some things I‚Äôve learnt and also some quick snippets of what I use on a day-to-day basis.
